_comment: This data is an early work-in-progress and contains errors. Produced by @michaelh at Discuss and Discover SuttaCentral forum - please get in touch! Finished code forthcoming.

Who is liable to decline and who is not: When a mendicant sees a sight with the eye, bad, unskillful phenomena arise
If that mendicant tolerates them and doesn’t give them up, get rid of them, eliminate them, and obliterate them, they are liable to decline
If that mendicant doesn’t tolerate them but gives them up, gets rid of them, eliminates them, and obliterates them, they are not liable to decline
The six fields of mastery (a causal chai: When a mendicant sees a sight with the eye, bad, unskillful phenomena don’t arise
When a mendicant hears a sound, bad, unskillful phenomena don’t arise
When a mendicant smells an odor, bad, unskillful phenomena don’t arise
When a mendicant tastes a flavor, bad, unskillful phenomena don’t arise
When a mendicant feels a touch, bad, unskillful phenomena don’t arise
When a mendicant knows a thought with the mind, bad, unskillful phenomena don’t arise
